Definition: A substance that provides nourishment essential for the maintenance of life and for growth.
The process of taking in food and using it for growth, metabolism, and repair.
The natural environment in which an organism lives, including all the physical and biological factors that influence life.
A group of living organisms of the same species, occupying a particular geographic area.
The scientific study of the relationships between living organisms and their environment.
The process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods with the help of chlorophyll.
A complex system of interdependent organisms and the physical environment they inhabit.
The process of gradual, natural change that takes place in an ecosystem over time.
The scientific study of the structure, properties, and behavior of matter and the changes it undergoes.
The branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.
The branch of biology that deals with the form, structure, and evolution of plants.
The branch of biology that deals with the structure and functions of cells.
The scientific study of animal behavior, including their actions and interactions with the environment.
The study of the physical, chemical, and biological conditions of the environment and the complex interactions of organisms.
The branch of biology that deals with the identification, naming, and classification of organisms.
The process of change in the inherited traits of a population of organisms from one generation to the next.
The branch of biology that deals with the study of animals, including their structure, functions, behavior, and evolution.
The branch of biology that deals with the study of fungi, including their structure, classification, and biological properties.
The branch of biology that deals with the study of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa.
The scientific study of the biological, physical, and chemical processes that occur within living organisms.
The flexible structure in the throat that allows air to pass into the trachea, also known as the windpipe.
The uppermost part of the respiratory system where air enters the body, consisting of the nose and mouth.
The tube connecting the throat (pharynx) with the stomach, responsible for the passage of food and liquids.
The sac-like organ located between the esophagus and the small intestine, responsible for storing and breaking down food.
The muscular organ in the chest responsible for pumping blood through the circulatory system.
The part of the respiratory system where gas exchange occurs, consisting of bronchioles and alveoli.
The small, finger-like projections lining the small intestine, responsible for absorbing nutrients into the bloodstream.
The large, tube-like organ responsible for processing waste and extracting water and salts before excretion.
The main organ of the central nervous system, responsible for processing and transmitting information throughout the body.
The longest nerve in the human body, running from the lower back down the leg and responsible for motor and sensory functions.
The network of tubes and vessels responsible for transporting blood throughout the body, including arteries, veins, and capillaries.
The external opening of the rectum, through which waste is expelled from the body during defecation.
The network of bones in the body, providing structure, support, and protection for internal organs.
The process of breaking down food into smaller molecules that can be absorbed and used by the body for energy and growth.
The fluid-filled sacs in the kidneys responsible for filtering waste products from the blood to form urine.
The outer layer of the skin, serving as a protective barrier against environmental factors.
The tube connecting the mouth and the stomach, responsible for swallowing food and liquids.
The small, sac-like organ located below the liver, responsible for storing and concentrating bile.
The process of breathing, involving the inhalation of oxygen and the exhalation of carbon dioxide.
The network of glands that produce hormones and regulate various bodily functions, including metabolism, growth, and reproduction.
